description: From Old French surrendre, from sur- + rendre (“render”). Noun use is from Anglo-Norman. Displaced native Old English handgang (noun) and on hand gān (verb).

entries.meaning: An act of surrendering, submission into the possession of another; abandonment, resignation.
The yielding or delivery of a possession in response to a demand.
(law, property law) The yielding of the leasehold estate by the lessee to the landlord, so that the tenancy for years merges in the reversion and no longer exists.

verbs.description: surrender (third-person singular simple present surrenders, present participle surrendering, simple past and past participle surrendered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give up into the power, control, or possession of another.
(military, by extension, transitive) To yield (a town, a fortification, etc.) to an enemy.
(intransitive or reflexive) To give oneself up into the power of another, especially as a prisoner; to submit or give in.
(transitive) To give up possession of; to yield; to resign.
examples: to surrender a right, privilege, or advantage

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To yield (oneself) to an influence, emotion, passion, etc.
examples: to surrender oneself to grief, to despair, to indolence, or to sleep

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, blackjack) To abandon (one's hand of cards) and recover half of the initial bet.
(transitive, insurance) For a policyholder, to voluntarily terminate an insurance contract before the end of its term, usually with the expectation of receiving a surrender value.
